entities.description: "Bullinaria and Levy are authors who contributed to the field of word embeddings, specifically in the context of SVD approximations."
"SGNS refers to a prediction-based shallow neural model used for dense word representations in the field of natural language processing."
"Blei and Lafferty are researchers who contributed to the field of dynamic topic modeling, which learns the evolution of topics over time."
"Wang and McCallum are researchers who have worked on dynamic topic modeling, contributing to the understanding of semantic shifts."
"Wijaya and Yeniterzi are researchers who used dynamic topic modeling to solve digital humanities tasks, such as finding traces of real-world events in texts."
"Heyer et al. are researchers who employed topic analysis to trace the 'context volatility' of words, contributing to the understanding of semantic shifts."
"Mueller and Rauh are political scientists who used topic models as proxies to social trends developing over time, including predicting the timing of civil wars and armed conflicts."
"Frermann and Lapata are researchers who drew on ideas from dynamic topic modeling to trace diachronic word senses development."
"Pennington et al. are researchers who contributed to the development of prediction-based embedding algorithms like SGNS, CBOW, or GloVe."

"Kulkarni et al. are researchers who suggested aligning word embedding models using linear transformations to fit them in one vector space, aiding in the comparison of word vectors across different models."
"Zhang et al. are researchers who proposed aligning diachronic word embedding models using a distance-preserving projection technique and later expanded on this by adding 'local anchors'."
"Eger and Mehler are researchers who compared word meaning using 'second-order embeddings,' analyzing the word's position compared to other words without requiring transformations."
"Hamilton et al. are researchers who showed that 'second-order embeddings' and orthogonal Procrustes transformations can be used simultaneously to align diachronic models."

"Bamler and Mandt are researchers who developed the 'dynamic skip-gram' model, allowing for learning word embeddings across several time periods jointly and enforcing alignment across all of them simultaneously."
"Yao et al. are researchers who developed the 'dynamic Word2Vec' model, which learns word embeddings across several time periods jointly and enforces alignment across all of them simultaneously."
"Rosenfeld and Erk are researchers who train a deep neural network on word and time representations, producing an embedding of word $w$ at time $t$."
"Kim et al. are researchers who proposed the idea of incrementally updated diachronic embedding models, allowing for incremental updates of the models with new data without any modifications."
"CBOW is a prediction-based embedding algorithm used for word vector representation in natural language processing."
"GloVe is a prediction-based embedding algorithm used for word vector representation in natural language processing."
"Mean Shift model is a method used for detecting 'bursts' in word meaning over time, as proposed by Taylor in 2000."
"Taylor is the author who proposed the Mean Shift model for detecting bursts in word meaning, contributing to the analysis of semantic shifts."

"Kulkarni et al. proposed using the Mean Shift model for detecting semantic shifts, indicating a direct relationship with this method."

"Bloomfield is an author who described semantic shifts along the spectrum from positive to negative."
"Blank and Koch are authors who contributed to the understanding of semantic shifts through their work in 1999."
"Grzega and Schoener are authors who have written about semantic shifts, specifically the causes which include linguistic, psychological, sociocultural, or cultural/encyclopedic factors."
"Hamilton et al. are researchers who have shown empirically the division of semantic shifts into linguistic drifts and cultural shifts."
"Stern is an author who classified semantic shifts, including the category of substitution which has a non-linguistic cause such as technological progress."
"Traugott is an author who has contributed to the study of lexical semantic shifts within general linguistics."
"Hilpert is an author who assumes that changes in a word’s collocational patterns reflect changes in word meaning."
"Gries is an author who supports the usage-based account of semantics, which aligns with the distributional semantic approach."
"Kerremans et al. are researchers who studied the neologism 'detweet' and its development of separate usages/meanings based on web-crawled data."
"Firth is an author who employed the distributional semantic approach, which is often used in NLP for studying meaning change over time."
"Gulordava and Baroni are researchers who showed that distributional models capture cultural shifts, like the word 'sleep' acquiring more negative connotations."
"Google Books Ngrams corpus is a dataset that has played a significant role in the development of the field of studying semantic shifts and 'culturomics.'"
"Michel et al. are researchers who contributed to the field of 'culturomics' by studying human culture through digital media, using the Google Books Ngrams corpus."
"Mihalcea and Nastase are researchers who used the Google Books Ngrams dataset to detect differences in word usage and meaning across 50-year time spans."
"Sagi et al. are researchers who studied long-term semantic shifts, specifically differences between Early Middle, Late Middle, and Early Modern English, using the Helsinki Corpus."
"Helsinki Corpus is a dataset used by researchers like Sagi et al. to study differences in language over long periods, such as changes in English from the Middle Ages to the Modern period."
"English meat is a term derived from Old English mete, which originally meant 'food', and now specifically refers to 'edible flesh'."
"Middle English dogge described a dog of a particular breed, and is an example of a more general term evolving into a more specific one, as in the word 'dog'."
"Old English cniht meant 'boy, servant' and is an example of a word that has evolved to a more elevated term, 'knight'."
"Knight is a term that has evolved from Old English cniht, which meant 'boy, servant', illustrating a semantic shift to a more elevated meaning."
"Ellipsis is a linguistic process where the meaning of one word is transferred to a word with which it frequently co-occurs, causing semantic shifts."
"Lexical borrowings from other languages can cause semantic shifts due to the need for discrimination of synonyms."
"Linguistic drifts refer to slow and regular changes in the core meaning of words, which are a type of semantic shift."
"Cultural shifts are culturally determined changes in associations of a given word, another type of semantic shift."
"Detweet is a neologism studied by Kerremans et al., showing the development of two separate usages/meanings: 'to delete from Twitter' and 'to avoid tweeting'."
"The distributional semantic approach is a method often employed in NLP, which aligns with the usage-based view of lexical semantics."
"Sleep is an example of a word that has acquired more negative connotations related to sleep disorders when comparing its contexts from the 1960s to the 1990s."

"Car is an example of a word that shifted its meaning from non-motorized vehicles to include motorized ones after the introduction of the automobile, illustrating a semantic shift due to technological progress."
"Early Middle English is a period in the historical development of the English language, used by researchers like Sagi et al. to study semantic shifts."
"Late Middle English is a period used by researchers to study semantic shifts, as in the work of Sagi et al. using the Helsinki Corpus."
"Early Modern English is a period in the development of the English language, studied by researchers like Sagi et al. for semantic shifts."
"Rissanen and others are associated with the creation of the Helsinki Corpus, which is used to study long-term semantic shifts in English."

entities.entity_name: "DIACHRONIC WORD EMBEDDINGS AND SEMANTIC SHIFTS DETECTION"
entities.description: "diachronic word embeddings and semantic shifts detection is the main topic of the paper, focusing on tracing temporal changes in lexical semantics."
"Mikolov et al. are referenced in the paper for their work on word embeddings, which became a widely used input representation for the task of capturing diachronic semantic shifts."
"Bréal is mentioned in the paper for their work on categorizing various types of semantic shifts."
"Stern is mentioned in the paper for their work on categorizing various types of semantic shifts."
"Bloomfield is referenced for their work on defining semantic shifts and proposing nine classes of semantic shifts."

"Geeraerts is mentioned in the paper for their studies inspired by Bloomfield's categorization of semantic shifts."
"Traugott and Dasher are mentioned in the paper for their studies inspired by Bloomfield's categorization of semantic shifts."

"the great vowel shift is mentioned as an example of laws of phonological change in the field of theoretical (diachronic) linguistics."
"lexical semantic shifts or semantic change is the focus of the paper, which is the evolution of word meaning over time."

"information retrieval is one of the three different research communities interested in diachronic word embeddings and semantic shifts."
"political science is one of the three different research communities interested in diachronic word embeddings and semantic shifts."
"topic modeling is mentioned as an example of other data-driven approaches employed to analyze temporal-labeled corpora."
"semantic shift is the central notion discussed in the paper, referring to changes in the meaning of words over time."
"word embeddings are the input representation used for capturing diachronic semantic shifts, as mentioned in the paper."
"co-occurrence data is used for producing dense vectors representing lexical meaning in word embeddings."
"statistical laws of semantic change is one of the particularly interesting results of diachronic embeddings research mentioned in the paper."
"temporal semantic relations is one of the particularly interesting results of diachronic embeddings research mentioned in the paper."
"systems that trace semantic shifts are discussed in the paper in terms of their possible applications."

entities.description: "Mihalcea and Nastase conducted research using a dataset to detect differences in word usage and meaning across 50-year time spans."
"Gulordava and Baroni compared word meanings in the 1960s and 1990s, achieving good correlation with human judgments."
"Google Ngrams is a corpus that does not contain full texts but has been used as a source of diachronic data in various studies."
"Mitra et al. employed syntactic ngrams to detect word sense changes over several different time periods."
"Kim et al. analyzed yearly changes of words, contributing to the study of socio-cultural semantic shifts."
"Liao and Cheng also analyzed yearly changes of words, focusing on the granularity of time spans."
"Rosenfeld and Erk proposed representing time as a continuous differentiable value in their research."
"Kulkarni et al. used Amazon Movie Reviews and Twitter data to show that computational methods can be applied to time spans less than a decade."
"Zhang et al. used the New-York Times Annotated Corpus to trace subtle semantic shifts."
"Szymanski employed 21 separate models, one for each year from 1987 to 2007, using the New-York Times Annotated Corpus."
"Yao et al. crawled the NYT website to get 27 yearly subcorpora for the study of semantic shifts."
"Eger and Mehler used the Corpus of Historical American (COHA) with time slices equal to one decade in their research."
"Hamilton et al. continued the usage of COHA along with the Google Ngrams corpus in their studies."
"Kutuzov et al. employed the yearly slices of the English Gigaword corpus in the analysis of cultural semantic drift related to armed conflicts."
"Traugott and Dasher conducted general linguistics research on language change, providing a small number of hand-picked examples."
"Popescu and Strapparava were involved in SemEval-2015 Task 7: ‘Diachronic Text Evaluation’."
"Twitter data was used by Kulkarni et al. to apply computational methods for detecting semantic shifts with a granularity of 1 month."
"The New-York Times Annotated Corpus was used by Zhang et al. to trace subtle semantic shifts and by Szymanski for yearly models from 1987 to 2007."
"The English Gigaword corpus was employed by Kutuzov et al. for the analysis of cultural semantic drift related to armed conflicts with yearly slices."
"The Corpus of Historical American (COHA) was used by Eger and Mehler with time slices equal to one decade for tracing semantic shifts."
"SemEval-2015 Task 7 was an event offering a problem similar to word epoch disambiguation for evaluating diachronic approaches."
"Cross-time alignment is an evaluation method where a system finds equivalents for certain words in different time periods."
"Parker et al. are associated with the English Gigaword corpus used in the analysis of cultural semantic drift."
"Syntactic ngrams are a method employed by Mitra et al. to detect word sense changes over different time periods."
"Diachronic corpora are used as a source of training data for developing semantic shift detection systems and as a source of test sets to evaluate such systems."
"Word epoch disambiguation is the ability of a system to detect the time span that specific contexts of a word undergoing a shift belong to."

entities.entity_name: "RANKING BY THE DEGREE OF THE SHIFT"
entities.description: "Ranking by the degree of the shift is an ideal way to evaluate diachronic approaches on human-annotated lists of semantically shifted words."
"General linguistics research on language change, such as that of Traugott and Dasher, provides a small number of hand-picked examples for evaluating semantic shifts."
"Real-world events, like armed conflicts, are used as a basis for evaluating detected diachronic semantic shifts to trace or predict such events."
"Self-created test sets are used by practitioners to evaluate semantic shift detection approaches when gold standard data is not available."
"Manually inspecting the results is a method used by practitioners to evaluate semantic shift detection when other evaluation methods are not feasible."
"A synthetic task is an approach to evaluate systems by merging two real words and modifying training and test data according to a predefined sense-shifting function."

"Mitra et al. continued the usage of the Google Ngrams corpus in their study of word sense changes."

entities.description: "The study by Kulkarni and colleagues in 2015 is an event in the timeline of research on semantic shifts, focusing on the drift of particular words."

"Diachronic Word Embeddings refer to the temporal word embeddings used for the computational detection of semantic shifts."
"Linguistic Drifts are changes in language that are separate from cultural shifts, as discussed by Hamilton et al. in 2016c."
"Cultural Shifts are changes in culture that may be reflected in language, as opposed to linguistic drifts."
"Semantic Shifts refer to changes in the meaning of words over time, which is the central focus of the research discussed in the text."
"Diachronic Embeddings are models used to study semantic shifts over time."
"Joint Learning Across Time Spans is a research direction for diachronic embeddings, as initiated by Bamler and Mandt in 2017."

"Sunny Mitra is an author who has published a paper on automatic identification of word sense change across different timescales."
"Ritwik Mitra is an author who has published a paper on automatic identification of word sense change across different timescales."
"Martin Riedl is an author who has published a paper on automatic identification of word sense change across different timescales."
"Chris Biemann is an author who has published a paper on automatic identification of word sense change across different timescales."
"Animesh Mukherjee is an author who has published a paper on automatic identification of word sense change across different timescales."
"Pawan Goyal is an author who has published a paper on automatic identification of word sense change across different timescales."
"Hannes Mueller is an author who has published a paper on prediction of political violence using newspaper text."
"Christofer Rauh is an author who has published a paper on prediction of political violence using newspaper text."
"Robert Parker is an author who has published a technical report on English Gigaword Fifth Edition."
"David Graff is an author who has published a technical report on English Gigaword Fifth Edition."
"Juola is an author who contributed to the study of semantic shifts through frequency analysis of words in web search queries."
"Hilpert and Gries are authors who researched change in raw word frequencies to trace semantic shifts or linguistic change."
"Michel et al. are researchers who contributed to the study of semantic shifts through frequency analysis of words."
"Lijffijt et al. are researchers who analyzed word frequencies to infer changes in meaning over time."
"Choi and Varian are authors who studied frequency analysis of words in web search queries for semantic shifts."
"Heyer et al. are researchers who studied the frequency of words collocating over time to infer changes in meaning."
"Turney et al. are authors who showed that distributional word representations provide an efficient way to solve semantic shift tasks."
"Baroni et al. are researchers who contributed to the understanding of word meaning through distributional word representations."
"Kulkarni et al. demonstrated that distributional models outperform frequency-based methods in detecting semantic shifts."
"Jurgens and Stevens are researchers who proposed using distributional methods to detect semantic shifts quantitatively."
"Kanerva et al. are the authors of the Random Indexing (RI) algorithm used to create word vectors."
"Gulordava and Baroni are researchers who used explicit count-based models for distributional word representations."
"Sagi et al. are researchers who used Latent Semantic Analysis for their distributional models."
"Baslave et al. proposed an extension to RI called Temporal Random Indexing (TRI) for distributional models."
"Mitra et al. are researchers who analyzed clusters of word similarity graphs for fine-grained semantic shift detection."
"Kim et al. are researchers who employed prediction-based word embedding models to trace diachronic semantic shifts."
"Hamilton et al. showed the superiority of SGNS over explicit PPMI-based distributional models in semantic shifts analysis."
"Mikolov et al. are authors who contributed to the development of Continuous Skipgram with negative sampling (SGNS)."
"Bullinaria and Levy are researchers who worked on low-rank SVD approximations for distributional models."
"Diachronic Data Set refers to a collection of data used to analyze changes over time, such as semantic shifts."
"Word Embedding Models are a technology used to represent words in vector space, capturing semantic relationships."
"Distributional Word Representations are a method of representing word meaning using vectors derived from co-occurrence counts."
"Random Indexing (RI) is an algorithm used to create word vectors for distributional models."
"Local Mutual Information is a measure used to weight co-occurrence matrices in count-based distributional models."
"Latent Semantic Analysis is a technique used to reduce the dimensionality of text data and identify semantic structures."
"Temporal Random Indexing (TRI) is an extension of the Random Indexing algorithm for diachronic analysis."
"Syntactic Dependency Contexts are grammatical relationships between words, used in determining word similarity."
"Mutual Information (MI) is a measure used to determine the saliency of syntactic dependency contexts."
"Continuous Skipgram with Negative Sampling (SGNS) is a prediction-based word embedding model."
"PPMI Matrices are matrices used in the creation of distributional models, representing Pointwise Mutual Information."
"Shallow Neural Models are a type of neural network used for tasks such as word embedding and semantic analysis."
"The Gutenberg Project is a source of texts used in the analysis of semantic shifts, particularly for the Italian examples."

relationships.description: "Random Indexing is an algorithm used in the creation of word embedding models."
"Local Mutual Information is used to weight co-occurrence matrices in distributional word representations."
"Latent Semantic Analysis is a technique used in creating distributional word representations."
"Temporal Random Indexing is an extension of the Random Indexing algorithm."

entities.description: "Kutuzov et al., 2016 is a research group that studied semantic shifts across models trained on texts produced by different political actors or written in different genres."

"Dubossarsky et al., 2017 is a research group that questioned the validity of some proposed 'laws' of semantic change and demonstrated that some regularities observed in previous studies are largely artifacts of the models used and frequency effects."
"Mikolov et al., 2013a is a research group known for their work on word embedding models, which successfully capture complex relationships between concepts."
"Zhang et al., 2015 is a research group that considered the temporal correspondences problem, identifying words in a target time period that correspond to a query term in the source time period."
"Szymanski, 2017 is a researcher who frames the temporal word analogy problem, extending the word analogies concept into the temporal dimension."
"Rosin et al., 2017 is a research group that studied the relatedness of words over time, answering queries like 'in which time period were the words Obama and president maximally related'."

"Kutuzov et al., 2017a is a research group that modeled a different semantic relation and used linear projections to trace the temporal dynamics of these relations, detecting lasting or emerging armed conflicts and the violent groups involved."
"Kulkarni et al., 2015 is a research group that tracked semantic drift of particular words."
"Hamilton et al., 2016b is a research group that tracked semantic drift of word sentiment."
"Sagi et al., 2011 is a research group that identified the breakpoints between epochs."
"Mihalcea and Nastase, 2012 is a research group that identified the breakpoints between epochs."
"Hamilton et al., 2016c is a research group that studied the laws of semantic change at scale."
"Chronologically shuffled data is a control dataset constructed by Dubossarsky et al., 2017, containing data from all decades evenly distributed."
"Synchronous variant is a control dataset used by Dubossarsky et al., 2017, containing repeated random samples from the year 1999 alone."
"Raw co-occurrence counts is a method used by Dubossarsky et al., 2017 in their experiments to measure semantic change."
"PPMI weighted counts is a method used by Dubossarsky et al., 2017 in their experiments to measure semantic change."
"SVD transformations (Procrustes aligned) is a method used by Dubossarsky et al., 2017 in their experiments to measure semantic change."
"Word analogies task is a well-known task in which word embedding models must 'solve' equations of the form 'A is to B is as C is to what?'"
"Distributional model is a type of model that captures the relation between words by adding and subtracting the corresponding word vectors."
"Obama and president is an example of a query used by Rosin et al., 2017 to study the relatedness of words over time."
"Linguistic studies involve investigating the how and why of semantic shifts, using corpora with longer time spans."
"Event detection approaches mine text data for actionable purposes, grouping applications of diachronic word embeddings into one broad category."
"武装冲突 is a term used by Kutuzov et al., 2017a in their study to detect lasting or emerging armed conflicts and the violent groups involved."
"暴力团体 refers to violent groups involved in armed conflicts, as studied by Kutuzov et al., 2017a."

relationships.description: "Dubossarsky et al., 2017 questioned the validity of some of the proposed 'laws' of semantic change by Kutuzov et al., 2016."
"Zhang et al., 2015 built upon the work of Mikolov et al., 2013a by considering the temporal correspondences problem in word embedding models."
"Szymanski, 2017 extended the work of Zhang et al., 2015 on temporal word analogies by framing it as a problem extending into the temporal dimension."
"Dubossarsky et al., 2017 constructed Chronologically shuffled data as a control dataset for their experiments."
"Dubossarsky et al., 2017 constructed Synchronous variant as a control dataset for their experiments."
"Dubossarsky et al., 2017 performed experiments using Raw co-occurrence counts to measure semantic change."

entities.description: "Kim et al. (2014) proposed the idea of incrementally updated diachronic embedding models, which train a model on one year and then initialize the next year's model with the word vectors from the previous year."

"Peng et al. (2017) described a novel method of incrementally learning the hierarchical softmax function for the CBOW and Continuous Skipgram algorithms, allowing for more efficient updates of word embedding models."

"Kaji and Kobayashi (2017) proposed an incremental extension for negative sampling, a method of training examples selection used with prediction-based models as a faster replacement for hierarchical softmax."

"Hamilton et al. (2016a) made an observation that the distinction between linguistic and cultural semantic shifts is correlated with the distinction between global and local embedding comparison methods."
"Hamilton et al. (2016c) contributed to the understanding of semantic shifts by differentiating between global and local embedding comparison methods."
"Dubossarsky et al. (2015) experimented with K-means clustering on SGNS embeddings and proposed the 'law of prototypicality' regarding semantic change."
"Dubossarsky et al. (2017) proposed that the likelihood for semantic shift correlates with the degree of prototypicality, known as the 'law of prototypicality'."
"Eger and Mehler (2016) postulated two 'laws' of semantic change based on their study of time-indexed historical corpora of English, German, and Latin."
"Xu and Kemp (2015) proposed the 'law of differentiation,' which states that the meaning of words tends to decay linearly in time."
"Azarbonyad et al. (2017) showed that the 'law of conformity' holds not only for diachronic corpora but also for other 'viewpoints'."
"Kutuzov et al. (2016) provided an example of how semantic shifts can be observed across models trained on texts produced by different political actors or written in different genres."
"Diachronic Embedding Models are models that are updated incrementally over time, as proposed by Kim et al. (2014), and are central to the discussion of semantic shifts and model comparisons."
"CBOW (Continuous Bag of Words) is an algorithm used for word embeddings, which Peng et al. (2017) improved with an incremental learning method for the hierarchical softmax function."
"Continuous Skipgram is an algorithm used for word embeddings, which Peng et al. (2017) improved with an incremental learning method for the hierarchical softmax function."
"Negative Sampling is a training examples selection method, widely used with prediction-based models, which Kaji and Kobayashi (2017) proposed an incremental extension for."

"Global Embedding Comparison Methods consider the whole model when comparing word vectors across different time periods, which Hamilton et al. (2016a) and Hamilton et al. (2016c) discussed in the context of semantic shifts."

"Local Embedding Comparison Methods focus on the immediate neighborhood of words when comparing word vectors across different time periods, which Hamilton et al. (2016a) and Hamilton et al. (2016c) discussed in the context of semantic shifts."
"Second-Order Embeddings are used to compare the similarities of a word to all other words in the lexicon, which Eger and Mehler (2016) used in their study of semantic shifts."
"The Law of Prototypicality, proposed by Dubossarsky et al. (2015) and (2017), states that the likelihood for semantic shift correlates with the degree of prototypicality of a word."
"The Law of Differentiation, proposed by Xu and Kemp (2015) and in line with Eger and Mehler's (2016) findings, states that the meaning of words tends to decay linearly in time."
"The Law of Conformity, proposed by Hamilton et al. (2016a), states that frequent words change more slowly in terms of semantic shifts."
"The Law of Innovation, proposed by Hamilton et al. (2016a), states that polysemous words change more quickly in terms of semantic shifts, controlled for frequency."
"Core Vocabulary refers to words occurring at least 100 times in all time periods, which Eger and Mehler (2016) used to enable comparison of embeddings across time."
"Procrustes-Aligned SVD Embeddings are used to represent words and quantify the rate of semantic change, as used by Hamilton et al. (2016a)."

relationships.description: "Both Kim et al. (2014) and Peng et al. (2017) are involved in the development of incremental updating methods for word embedding models."
"Peng et al. (2017) and Kaji and Kobayashi (2017) are both involved in the incremental updating of word embedding models, with Kaji and Kobayashi focusing on negative sampling."
"Hamilton et al. (2016a) and Hamilton et al. (2016c) both contributed to the understanding of global and local embedding comparison methods for semantic shifts."

entities.description: "Gustaf Stern is the author of the work 'Meaning and change of meaning; with special reference to the English language' published in 1931."

"Terrence Szymanski is the author of the paper 'Temporal word analogies: Identifying lexical replacement with diachronic word embeddings' presented at the 55th Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics in 2017."
"Wayne A Taylor is the author of the work 'Change-point analysis: a powerful new tool for detecting changes' published in 2000."
"Elizabeth Closs Traugott is a co-author of the book 'Regularity in semantic change' published in 2001 and also authored 'Semantic change' in 2017 for Oxford Research Encyclopedias: Linguistics."
"Richard B Dasher is a co-author of the book 'Regularity in semantic change' published in 2001."
"Peter Turney is a co-author of the paper 'From frequency to meaning: Vector space models of semantics' published in the Journal of artificial intelligence research in 2010."
"Patrick Pantel is a co-author of the paper 'From frequency to meaning: Vector space models of semantics' published in the Journal of artificial intelligence research in 2010."

"Xuerui Wang is a co-author of the paper 'Topics over time: a non-markov continuous-time model of topical trends' presented at the 12th ACM SIGKDD international conference on Knowledge discovery and data mining in 2006."

"Andrew McCallum is a co-author of the paper 'Topics over time: a non-markov continuous-time model of topical trends' presented at the 12th ACM SIGKDD international conference on Knowledge discovery and data mining in 2006."

"Derry Tanti Wijaya is a co-author of the paper 'Understanding semantic change of words over centuries' presented at the 2011 international workshop on Detecting and Exploiting Cultural diversity on the social web."

"Reyyan Yeniterzi is a co-author of the paper 'Understanding semantic change of words over centuries' presented at the 2011 international workshop on Detecting and Exploiting Cultural diversity on the social web."
"Yang Xu is a co-author of the paper 'A computational evaluation of two laws of semantic change' presented at the 37th Annual Meeting of the Cognitive Science Society in 2015."
"Charles Kemp is a co-author of the paper 'A computational evaluation of two laws of semantic change' presented at the 37th Annual Meeting of the Cognitive Science Society in 2015."
"Zijun Yao is a co-author of the paper 'Dynamic word embeddings for evolving semantic discovery' presented at the Eleventh ACM International Conference on Web Search and Data Mining in 2018."
"Yifan Sun is a co-author of the paper 'Dynamic word embeddings for evolving semantic discovery' presented at the Eleventh ACM International Conference on Web Search and Data Mining in 2018."
"Weicong Ding is a co-author of the paper 'Dynamic word embeddings for evolving("entity"
"Hui Xiong is a co-author of the paper 'Dynamic word embeddings for evolving semantic discovery' presented at the Eleventh ACM International Conference on Web Search and Data Mining in 2018."

"Yating Zhang is a co-author of two papers: 'Omnia mutantur, nihil interit: Connecting past with present by finding corresponding terms across time' and 'The past is not a foreign country: Detecting semantically similar terms across time'."

"Adam Jatowt is a co-author of two papers with Yating Zhang: 'Omnia mutantur, nihil interit: Connecting past with present by finding corresponding terms across time' and 'The past is not a foreign country: Detecting semantically similar terms across time'."
"Sourav Bhowmick is a co-author of the paper 'Omnia mutantur, nihil interit: Connecting past with present by finding corresponding terms across time'."

"Katsumi Tanaka is a co-author of two papers with Yating Zhang: 'Omnia mutantur, nihil interit: Connecting past with present by finding corresponding terms across time' and 'The past is not a foreign country: Detecting semantically similar terms across time'."
"Sourav S. Bhowmick is a co-author of the paper 'The past is not a foreign country: Detecting semantically similar terms across time'."
